details.title: (s,Q) Spare Parts Provisioning Strategy for Periodically Replaced Systems

p: Claver Diallo received the BS (1995), MScA (2005), and PhD (2006) degrees in mechanical engineering from Université Laval, Québec, Canada. From 1996 to 1999, he worked as a Field Engineer for Schlumberger Oilfield Services. He is currently working as a post-doctoral researcher in industrial engineering at Université Laval. His main research interests include maintenance and availability optimization, inventory control, sustainable design, and life cycle engineering.

Daoud Aït-Kadi received the MScA (1980), and PhD (1985) degrees in computer science, and operational research from the École Polytechnique of Montréal, Canada. He worked as an assistant professor from 1980 to 1985 at the École Polytechnique, and at the Université du Québec in Montreal, before being hired as professor at the Université du Québec à Trois-Rivières. Since 1990, he has been working as professor at Université Laval in the mechanical engineering department. He is also director of the industrial engineering graduate program. His main research interests include maintenance and reliability optimization, design and control of logistics networks, sustainable development, and reverse logistics. He is a senior member of IEEE. He serves on the editorial board of the Journal of Quality and Maintenance Engineering.

Anis Chelbi received the BS (1992), MScA (1994), and PhD (1996) degrees in mechanical engineering from Université Laval, Québec, Canada. From 1996 to 1998, he worked as assistant professor in mechanical engineering at Université Laval. Since 1998, he has been working as a professor in mechanical engineering at the École Supérieure des Sciences et Techniques de Tunis, Tunisia. His main research interests include maintenance and reliability optimization, CMMS design and implementation strategies, production, and inventory systems modeling.

details.abstract: A joint preventive maintenance and spare parts provisioning strategy is suggested for a failure prone system. Replacements are carried-out at failure, if spare parts are available, and at spare parts replenishment delivery instants. Spare parts are provisioned according to an (s, Q) control policy. The ordering parameters, and preventive maintenance interval are derived from a mathematical model which aims at maximizing the system's availability under a budget constraint. The model takes into account the system lifetime distribution, the preventive and corrective maintenance costs and durations, as well as the total spare parts inventory management cost. Unlike classical inventory management models, the s-expected total cost is derived using the system lifetime distribution. Because each demand for spare parts is triggered by failure, the probabilities of shortage, and surplus will be evaluated based on the system failure distribution rather than the demand distribution during the lead-time. Numerical results have been obtained for an illustrative example.

links.abstract: An experiment is presented that explores if and how different users of the same decision-support system (DSS) differ in their perceptions of system restrictiveness. Subjects used three DSSs and ranked them from most to least restrictive. The results indicated that while there was a significant similarity among rankings, there were also substantial differences. Several factors contributing to the perceptual differences were identified; these can serve as the basis for further research.
